Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>... Is it beneficial to implement 
>>dormant genes in NEAT?
>>
>>    
>>
>
>A lot of the discussion about how NEAT does not simplify is slightly
>misleading.  NEAT *does* have a mutation operator that flips enable
>bits to "disabled" with random probability.  It's just that I never
>actually used this kind of mutation in the experiments I ran.  The
>reason I didn't use it was so that we don't have too many opposing
>processes happening at the same time, which would make the analysis of
>the algorithm too convoluted.
>
Absolutely. One of my goals this time around is to keep everything as 
simple as possible, with a view to switching additional functionality on 
later. My previous EANN attempt using tree based genomes became a little 
convoluted. I feel like I need to take a step back and perhaps build up 
to implementing a tree structure again later.


>  But there is nothing about the system
>itself that prevents one from allowing genes to become randomly
>disabled, and my current implementation has such a mutation available.
> (muate_toggle_enable in the .ne file).  
>
>That said, I've tried using it, and didn't find any dramatic
>improvement in performance, although I absolutely believe more
>experiments with the idea of complexification with pruning are
>merited, especially over long term evolution.  
>
>  
>
I think we all agree on this :)

>I should also note that as Derek said, NEAT does disable genes when it
>adds a node, and there is some probability during mating that a
>disabled gene may become reenabled.  I only mention this to point out
>you will see disabled genes occasionally even without another mutation
>operator.
>  
>
Understood.

>Also note that the proper way to simplify in NEAT is to disable,
>because if you literally cut out a gene, you lose that historical
>information, which is still useful for compatibility determination.
>
>  
>
Yes and they may possibly become useful further down an evolution run, 
unlikely but possible.

Colin
